text:
Protect yourself and family from mosquito-borne illness. Drain standing water and fix leaks, wear long layers and repellent, and stay indoors with intact screens if possible.

text:
With school starting, remember #CyberSecurity is a must. Keep personal information private. Only open emails from folks you know. Never give out passwords, and know who you're talking to online.

text:
Trivia Time:

If someone appears to be suffering from heat stroke, which of the following should be done first:

A.   Call 9-1-1
B.   Give the person cool water to sip
C.   Remove excess clothing
D.   Check their mental status with a short memory quiz

@CityOfDallas @DallasPD

text:
What I learned at the @DallasOEM mass casualty event today
First Responders will not enter a building unless it's secure.  
Save yourself,  Get out or get away from the situation to a safe distance if you can. 
Stop the bleeding on yourself and then the person next to you. pic.twitter.com/0jBpGwX5u3
text_html: What I learned at the @DallasOEM mass casualty event today First Responders will not enter a building unless it's secure. Save yourself, Get out or get away from the situation to a safe distance if you can. Stop the bleeding on yourself and then the person next to you. pic.twitter.com/0jBpGwX5u3
username: Marko Sakal

text: This summer - no matter where you are or what you're doing - practice #FoodSafety. Wash hands often, separate meat from other foods, cook everything to a safe temperature, and keep hot foods hot, and cold foods cold. Store your leftovers quickly. @DallasFireRes_q @CityOfDallaspic.twitter.com/DRrTIkdhVb

text: July is Sun Safety month. Protect yourself from the sun by staying in shade. Wear long, loose layers, hats, and sunglasses that block UVA/UVB rays - and don't forget the suncreen. Drink plenty of water and other fluids. pic.twitter.com/f6a1MxIt3P
text_html: July is Sun Safety month. Protect yourself from the sun by staying in shade. Wear long, loose layers, hats, and sunglasses that block UVA/UVB rays - and don't forget the suncreen. Drink plenty of water and other fluids. pic.twitter.com/f6a1MxIt3P
username: City of Dallas Office of Emergency Management

text:
Trivia Time:
To protect yourself from mosquito-borne diseases, how often should you apply insect repellent?

A. Every 30 minutes
B. Every hour
C. It depends on the percentage of active ingredient 
D. Insect repellent does not protect against mosquito-borne 
     diseases

text: Summer heat is just as bad for pets as it is for people. Over 65
A first responder/medical professional
a @dartmedia driver

You can protect yourself and others from viruses like cold and flu.

-- Cover coughs/sneezes
-- Avoid touching face and eyes
-- Wash hands often
-- Stay home if you feel sick/feverish
-- Get a flu shot

text:
Winter's here, and with it wind chills. In cold, calm weather, the body radiates heat that creates a layer of warmth. In cold, windy weather, the wind moves heat away from the body making it feel colder.
